docs.lead_paragraph: In 2003, Britain plans to undertake the world's most ambitious study of the origins of disease. Looking forward to the day when people will know their genetic makeups and request a precise picture of their risks of developing various diseases, the study organizers plan to assemble a database of medical information about 500,000 Britons, including their DNA.

headline.main: To Study Disease, Britain Plans a Genetic Census

docs.abstract: Article on genetic makeup study planned by British government in 2003; oganizers plan to assemble database of medical information on about 500,000 Britons, including their DNA, in effort to determine way that genes and environment combine to cause common diseases; photos; maps; chart (M)
docs.snippet: In 2003, Britain plans to undertake the world's most ambitious study of the origins of disease.    Looking forward to the day when people will know their genetic makeups and request a precise picture of their risks of developing various diseases, the...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the course of the last year, the woman lost her husband to cancer and then her job. But she did not come to my office as a patient; she sought advice about her teenage son who was having trouble dealing with his father's death. Despite crushing loss and stress, she was not at all depressed -- sad, yes, but still upbeat. I found myself stunned by her resilience. What accounted for her ability to weather such sorrow with buoyant optimism? So I asked her directly.

headline.main: Born to Be Happy, Through a Twist of Human Hard Wire

docs.abstract: Article on hyperthymia, temperament that makes some people abnormally happy, extroverted and full of energy and enthusiasm; seen as psychiatric mirror image of dysthymia, a chronic, mild depression; some negative aspects of hyperthymia noted; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Your Skin from A to Z,'' by Dr. Jerome Z. Litt. Barricade, $14.95. If laid out flat, the skin of an average adult would cover some 20 square feet and weigh about 9 pounds, making it the largest human organ. It is also, writes the author of this informative guide to ''the house we live in,'' the body's most abused and maligned organ.
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book Your Skin from A to Z by Dr Jerome Z Litt; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''His Prostate and Me,'' by Desiree Lyon Howe. Winedale Publishing, $16. Books on prostate cancer are invariably written by the men who suffer from it; this one approaches the disease from a woman's perspective.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study finds that grape seed extract may be a powerful tool in the treatment of skin wounds. Writing in a recent issue of Free Radical Biology and Medicine, researchers said they had evidence that when placed on wounds, the extract promoted the regeneration of damaged blood vessels and the production of free radicals, which fight bacteria that cause infection.

headline.main: Relief That Lies in the Grape Seed

docs.abstract: Research team from Ohio State University Heart and Lung Research Institute, reporting in recent issue of Free Radical Biology and Medicine, finds evidence that grape seed extract, when placed on wounds, promotes regeneration of damaged blood vessels and production of free radicals, which fight infectious bacteria; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Having a chronic illness like emphysema is often not enough to push people to quit smoking, a new study reports. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, part of the federal Department of Health and Human Services, said last week that 37.9 percent of patients with emphysema had said in a survey that they continued to smoke.

headline.main: Gasping for Air, but Still Smoking

docs.abstract: Survey conducted by Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality finds that 37.9 percent of emphysema patients and 24.8 percent of asthma patients continue to smoke; finds that 23 percent of whites and non-Hispanics smoke, compared with 16.8 percent of Hispanics; reports that 32.8 percent of people with less than high school education smoke, compared with 15.8 percent with more than 12 years of education (M)
docs.snippet: Having a chronic illness like emphysema is often not enough to push people to quit smoking, a new study reports.    The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, part of the federal Department of Health and Human Services, said last week that 37.9...

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the course of a decade, despite trying every conceivable healthy way to lose weight and to keep it off, Sharon Clapp watched with alarm as her weight soared to 320 pounds from 220. Now 62 and about to become a grandmother for the second time, Mrs. Clapp, who is from St. Paul, had to face facts: physically, by some miracle, she was still healthy (and she wanted to stay that way), but she could not tie her own shoes, walk uphill unaided or travel to distant lands for fear she would not fit in narrow bus and airline seats. Nor did she want her grandchildren to grow up embarrassed by a hugely fat grandmother who could not take proper care of them.

headline.main: Surgical Alternatives for the Truly Overweight

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on bariatric surgery, which greatly restricts size of stomach and length of intestine, only truly successful weight-loss technique for the morbidly obese; describes case of Sharon Clapp, 62, who underwent surgery and lost 170 pounds; describes operations and candidates; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Couples who are trying to have a baby should focus their efforts on the days leading up to ovulation, not on the day of ovulation itself, a new report advises. The article, in this month's issue of Obstetrics & Gynecology, suggests that the best time to have intercourse may be the day before a woman ovulates. Repeated intercourse in the five days before ovulation will probably increase the odds of conception, the article said.
docs.abstract: University of Utah researchers, reporting in Obstetrics & Gynecology, suggest that best time to try to conceive baby is five days leading up to ovulation, not day of ovulation itself; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A drink or two a day provides the equivalent of a potent cholesterol medicine and a weak blood thinner, as well as a variety of other substances that may keep the body's metabolism tuned and its cells in good repair. Alcohol raises the blood levels of H.D.L., the ''good'' cholesterol, thought to scour blood vessels free of the fatty plaques that can cause heart attacks, strokes and other problems. Moderate drinking can raise the levels more than 10 percent. Heavy drinking raises them even higher.

headline.main: How a Tonic Keeps the Parts Well Oiled

docs.abstract: Article explains how drink or two a day could lower cholesterol, act as weak blood thinner and keep body's metabolism tuned and its cells in good repair; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers say they have direct evidence that the mood changes many people experience when winter comes and the days grow shorter have a physiological basis in the brain. Writing in a recent issue of The Lancet, researchers from the Baker Heart Research Institute in Australia say that concentrations of a chemical messenger in the brain rise and fall in relation to the amount of sunlight. The chemical, serotonin, has been linked to depression.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Baker Heart Research Institute in Australia, reporting in The Lancet, say concentrations of serotonin in brain rise and fall in relation to amount of sunlight, evidence that mood changes many people experience during shorter winter days have psysiological basis; drawing (M)
